citations.desc: Attending veterinarian and adequate veterinary care (dealers and exhibitors).
citations.narrative:
During the inspection, a female pygmy goat, approximately 8 months old, was found to be toe touching lame on its right
rear leg. When encouraged to walk, the goat would touch her right rear toes to the ground but not bear weight on the leg.
When standing, she would hold the leg slightly off the ground. Once caught and examined, the right rear leg was
significantly swollen down near the foot and warm to the touch, compared to the normal left rear leg. Additionally, the
animal had yellow, crusty discharge around both eyes as well as mild nasal discharge. The facility representative told me
that he noticed the animal limping about 2 weeks ago and have been monitoring it since. The facility representative had
not noticed the eye and nasal discharge. The attending veterinarian had not been notified of the abnormal condition of the
animal and veterinary care has not been provided to evaluate the goat's leg.
Daily observation of all animals shall be made to assess their health and well-being and promptly identify injuries,
disease, and other medical conditions. A mechanism of direct and frequent communication is required so that timely and
accurate information on problems of animal health, behavior, and well-being is conveyed to the attending veterinarian.
Untreated injuries, infections, and other conditions can be painful and cause suffering to the animal, and frequent
communications with the attending veterinarian are required to allow for the veterinarian to advise licensees on needed
treatments for health concerns, which helps to mitigate the effects of adverse health conditions. Correct by ensuring the
female goat is evaluated by a veterinarian and that treatments and care are followed.
This inspection and exit interview were conducted with the facility representatives.
n

narrative:
2.40(b)(3)  Direct Repeat
   
Attending veterinarian and adequate veterinary care (dealers and exhibitors). 
During the inspection, a female pygmy goat, approximately 8 months old, was found to be toe touching lame on its right 
rear leg. When encouraged to walk, the goat would touch her right rear toes to the ground but not bear weight on the leg. 
When standing, she would hold the leg slightly off the ground. Once caught and examined, the right rear leg was 
significantly swollen down near the foot and warm to the touch, compared to the normal left rear leg. Additionally, the 
animal had yellow, crusty discharge around both eyes as well as mild nasal discharge. The facility representative told me 
that he noticed the animal limping about 2 weeks ago and have been monitoring it since. The facility representative had 
not noticed the eye and nasal discharge. The attending veterinarian had not been notified of the abnormal condition of the 
animal and veterinary care has not been provided to evaluate the goat's leg.  
 
Daily observation of all animals shall be made to assess their health and well-being and promptly identify injuries, 
disease, and other medical conditions. A mechanism of direct and frequent communication is required so that timely and 
accurate information on problems of animal health, behavior, and well-being is conveyed to the attending veterinarian. 
Untreated injuries, infections, and other conditions can be painful and cause suffering to the animal, and frequent 
communications with the attending veterinarian are required to allow for the veterinarian to advise licensees on needed 
treatments for health concerns, which helps to mitigate the effects of adverse health conditions. Correct by ensuring the 
female goat is evaluated by a veterinarian and that treatments and care are followed. 
 
This inspection and exit interview were conducted with the facility representatives.
